page.title: 09Lullington Heath
page.content: Lullington Heath,National Nature Reserve,the best example in England of rare chalk heath,has alkaline sub-soil and strata covered by a sandy top-soil which is sufficiently neutral for both chalk-loving and acid-loving plants to flourish.Sheep-rearing declined, myxomatosis hit the rabbit population, so lack of grazing caused the natural sward to become overgrown with gorse. The natural sward has been restored by mechanical cutting and enclosed areas are grazed by sheep and ponies.The central swathe is open to the public, other areas are for specialist study. Heathers,red betony,scabious and wood-sage abound(August).Low growing plants and turf teem with grasshoppers while several butterfly types feed on the flowers.Rabbit holes and excreta suggest an active rabbit population, holes indicate smaller mammals.
